name: Friedmann Equation
description: Describes how the expansion rate of the Universe depends on its geometry and the density of matter and energy within it. The term (a-dot/a) is the Hubble parameter H(t), rho is the total density, k is the spatial curvature parameter, and a is the scale factor

name: Relativistic Friedmann Equation
description: The general relativistic form of the Friedmann equation where the density term rho is replaced by energy density epsilon divided by c squared, reflecting that energy (not just rest mass) determines gravitational influence

name: Relativistic Energy of a Particle
description: The relativistic expression for the energy of a single particle with rest mass m0 and momentum p

name: First Law of Thermodynamics (Cosmological)
description: The first law of thermodynamics applied to an expanding spherical region of the universe, where dQ/dt = 0 due to homogeneity preserving no temperature gradients

name: Fluid Equation
description: Describes how the energy densities and pressures of different fluids evolve in an expanding universe. The density term represents dilution while the pressure term arises from work done as the volume expands

name: Acceleration Equation
description: Describes the change in the rate at which the Universe expands. Increasing density or pressure slows expansion (reduces the rate at which scale factor increases)

name: Equation of State for a Perfect Fluid
description: Relates the pressure P of a perfect fluid to its density rho through the equation of state parameter w. Different values of w describe different types of cosmic fluid

name: Equation of State for Matter
description: For non-relativistic matter (pressureless dust), the equation of state parameter w_m = 0, giving zero pressure. This applies to both baryonic matter and dark matter

name: Ideal Gas Law (Cosmological Form)
description: The ideal gas law written in terms of pressure P, temperature T, mean particle mass mu, density rho, and Boltzmann constant k_B

name: Fluid Equation for Matter
description: The fluid equation simplified for pressureless matter, showing that the rate of change of matter density is proportional to the expansion rate

name: Scale Factor Dependence of Matter Density
description: Shows that matter density decreases as the cube of the scale factor as the Universe expands, reflecting the dilution of matter in an expanding volume

name: Friedmann Equation (Flat Matter-Dominated)
description: The Friedmann equation simplified for a flat (k=0) universe dominated by matter

name: Scale Factor Evolution (Matter-Dominated)
description: How the scale factor evolves with time in a flat, matter-dominated universe, where t0 = (6 pi G rho_m,0)^(-1/2) is the present age

name: Time Dependence of Matter Density
description: How matter density evolves with time in a flat, matter-dominated universe

name: Equation of State for Radiation
description: For relativistic radiation fluids (photons, neutrinos), the equation of state parameter w_r = 1/3, giving pressure equal to one-third of the energy density

name: Scale Factor Dependence of Radiation Density
description: Radiation density decreases as the fourth power of the scale factor - the extra factor of a compared to matter comes from photon wavelength stretching

name: Friedmann Equation (Flat Radiation-Dominated)
description: The Friedmann equation simplified for a flat (k=0) universe dominated by radiation

name: Time Dependence of Radiation Density
description: How radiation density evolves with time in a flat, radiation-dominated universe

name: Friedmann Equation (Mixed Universe)
description: The Friedmann equation for a universe containing both matter and radiation, using the total density

name: Friedmann Equation (Flat Universe)
description: The Friedmann equation for a spatially flat universe where k=0 and rho equals the critical density

name: Critical Density
description: The density required for the Universe to be spatially flat if the Hubble parameter has a particular value. This is a time-dependent quantity

name: Present Critical Density
description: The critical density evaluated at the present time using the Hubble constant H0

name: Density Parameter
description: The dimensionless ratio of the actual density to the critical density. For flat universes Omega = 1 always

name: Friedmann Equation (Density Parameter Form)
description: The Friedmann equation rewritten in terms of the density parameter, showing the relationship between Omega and spatial curvature k

name: Present-day Density-Curvature Relation
description: The relationship between the present density parameter Omega_0 and the curvature parameter k, using the convention a(t0) = 1

name: Total Density Parameter (Component Form)
description: The total density parameter expressed as the sum of matter and radiation density parameters

name: Effective Curvature Density Parameter
description: An effective density parameter for curvature that allows the Friedmann equation to be written compactly

name: Compact Friedmann Equation
description: The Friedmann equation written in its most compact form using density parameters

name: Friedmann Equation with Cosmological Constant
description: The Friedmann equation including the cosmological constant Lambda, which acts as a repulsive term that can accelerate expansion

name: Acceleration Equation with Cosmological Constant
description: The acceleration equation including the cosmological constant. Positive Lambda increases the acceleration of expansion

name: Cosmological Constant as Fluid Density
description: The cosmological constant expressed as an equivalent constant energy density, treating Lambda as a third fluid component

name: Density Parameter for Lambda
description: The density parameter for the cosmological constant in terms of Lambda and the Hubble parameter

name: Total Density Parameter with Lambda
description: The complete expression for total density parameter including matter, radiation, and cosmological constant contributions

name: Friedmann Equation (Full Density Parameter Form)
description: The Friedmann equation written entirely in terms of present-day density parameters, useful for modeling universes with multiple components

name: Friedmann Equation (Matter and Lambda Only)
description: Simplified Friedmann equation for a universe where radiation density is negligible compared to matter and cosmological constant

name: Deceleration Parameter
description: A dimensionless quantity that measures whether the expansion of the Universe is accelerating (q0 < 0) or decelerating (q0 > 0)

name: Scale Factor Taylor Expansion
description: Taylor expansion of the scale factor around the present time, used to derive the deceleration parameter

name: Scale Factor Expansion (H0 and q0 Form)
description: The Taylor expansion of the scale factor expressed in terms of the Hubble constant and deceleration parameter

name: Deceleration Parameter (Density Parameter Form)
description: Expression for the deceleration parameter in terms of matter and cosmological constant density parameters. Shows that Lambda > Omega_m/2 leads to accelerating expansion
